Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The nervous system of the Nine-banded Armadillo (Dasypus novemcinctus)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how brains become organized into specialized regions (touch, motor, vision, etc.) is essential to understanding how brains develop, as well as how they might be impacted and potentially repaired following developmental disorders or injuries. An effective strategy for acquiring a better understanding of brain organization involves examining mammals that possess unique body structures and behaviors. The goal of these studies is to characterize the organization and function of brain regions in the nine-banded armadillo (Dasypus novemcinctus), utilizing anatomical and electrophysiological recording methods. This project will reveal how mammalian nervous systems process specialized sensory inputs. Armadillos are covered in bony plates and are highly dependent upon their sense of hearing. These traits are expected to impact the brain regions responsible for touch, movement and hearing; understanding this relationship will shed light on analogous systems in other mammals such as humans. In addition to possessing sensory specializations, armadillos also uniquely give birth to identical quadruplets (basically clones), setting the stage for related neurodevelopmental studies with identical littermates for comparison, an ideal experimental situation unattainable with any other mammalian developmental model.

These studies will take place at the University of Central Arkansas and involve training undergraduate and master's students, many of whom are first generation college students, in cutting edge neurobiology research methods. Participating students will engage in the scientific process in a comprehensive hands-on manner, and gain research experience that will prepare them to pursue careers in neurobiology or other related STEM fields. The intense interest this work has generated in the pilot stages indicates that the incorporated educational outreach programs will help address a serious need for science education, particularly among Arkansas grade school students, where approximately 40% of those assessed perform below basic achievement levels (2011 Nation's Report Card, National Assessment of Educational Programs, U.S. Department of Education).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to reveal the structural and functional organization of the brain in the nine-banded armadillo (Dasypus novemcinctus), a member of Xenarthra, one of the earliest groups, or clades, of placental mammals to have emerged. Obtaining a complete picture of mammalian brain evolution requires examination of brains of specimens from all the major mammalian clades in order to distinguish between features of nervous systems that are common to all mammals and those that are restricted to particular groups. Armadillos are the only xenarthrans currently inhabiting the North American continent, and despite their prevalence across much of the southeastern United States, relatively little is known about their neurobiology. By studying armadillo sensory systems using a range of modern neuroscience methods, we aimed to provide key insights into xenarthran neurobiology and a better understanding of the evolution of mammalian nervous systems. Training graduate and undergraduate students as well as engaging in neuroscience outreach within central Arkansas were also key components of this project.

With regard to intellectual merit, major contributions of this project to our understanding of mammalian neurobiology included determining that 1) armadillos can hear a relatively broad range of frequencies and these frequencies are represented in the auditory structures of the brain similarly to other more recently emerged mammals, 2) armadillos have multiple brain areas that represent inputs from the skin, 3) armadillo visual cortex exhibits features shared with later derived groups, suggesting that basic computational properties of visual cortex are conserved across placental mammals, and 4) a striking modular anatomy is evident within sensory cortex of armadillos, and may be characteristic of members of this clade. Collaborations between the University of Central Arkansas and both the University of Arkansas at Little Rock and the University of Texas at Austin have been established as a result of this project. Four graduate students and six undergraduate students presented posters at annual meetings of the Society for Neuroscience, and two manuscripts, including a chapter on xenarthran neurobiology in Elsevier’s four volume Evolution of Nervous Systems, were published during the funding period. Four additional manuscripts are in progress.

In terms of broader impacts, this project provided opportunities for four master’s students to conduct thesis research and receive training in state of the art neurobiology methods. One is now in a neurobiology doctoral program, another is currently completing thesis research, and two others took positions as pharmacy or medical technicians. In addition, more than twenty undergraduate students directly participated in this work. So far, nine of these have entered competitive graduate programs or begun their pursuit of careers in medicine or pharmacy. More than half of these students were women, who are typically underrepresented in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) disciplines, and several were first generation college students. Nearly every student who worked on this study engaged in outreach events in which neurobiology research was presented to the general public (often elementary school students). This type of engagement between the scientific community and the public plays an important role in inspiring future scientific leaders within the state of Arkansas.
